content:
**"Personal Effects"** means items of personal use, worn or carried by You.

**"Pre-Existing Medical Condition"** means any condition which is in existence within one hundred and eighty-two (182) days prior to the commencement of Your Trip, regardless of whether:
* a) You have received medical treatment, diagnosis, consultation or prescribed drugs; or
* b) Symptoms or manifestations have existed; or
* c) Treatment was actually sought or received; or
* d) A reasonable person in the circumstances would be expected to be aware of the condition.
This definition of Pre-Existing Medical Condition shall also apply to Your Immediate Family Member or Travelling Companion or any person upon whose good health Your Trip depends.
questions: How does the definition of Pre-Existing Medical Condition apply to You, Your Immediate Family Member, Travelling Companion, or any person upon whose good health Your Trip depends, and what implications does this have for coverage eligibility?
In what ways does the 182-day look-back period for Pre-Existing Medical Conditions affect the assessment of coverage for medical issues arising during the Trip?
How does the policy treat Pre-Existing Medical Conditions that have not been diagnosed or treated but have had symptoms or manifestations within 182 days before the Trip?

What is the significance of the clause stating that a reasonable person would be expected to be aware of a Pre-Existing Medical Condition, and how might this impact claims related to undisclosed conditions?
How does the definition of Personal Effects as items of personal use worn or carried by You influence the scope of coverage for lost or damaged belongings during the Trip?
In cases where a Pre-Existing Medical Condition exists but no treatment or consultation was sought, how does the policy determine whether such a condition is covered or excluded?
How might the inclusion of Travelling Companion's Pre-Existing Medical Conditions in the definition affect coverage for trip cancellation or interruption claims?
What documentation or evidence might be required to establish whether a medical condition qualifies as Pre-Existing under the 182-day criterion?
How does the policy address situations where the health of a person upon whom Your Trip depends is compromised due to a Pre-Existing Medical Condition?
How do the definitions of Personal Effects and Pre-Existing Medical Condition interact when a medical device or wearable item is lost or damaged during the Trip?
In what scenarios could the definition of Pre-Existing Medical Condition lead to denial of claims related to medical emergencies during the Trip?
How does the policy differentiate between symptoms or manifestations that indicate a Pre-Existing Medical Condition and new medical conditions arising during the Trip?
What are the implications for coverage if a Pre-Existing Medical Condition was known to You but not disclosed at the time of purchasing the policy?
How does the policy treat Pre-Existing Medical Conditions in relation to optional covers or riders that may be purchased to extend coverage?
How might the definition of Personal Effects exclude certain items from coverage based on their use or whether they are worn or carried during the Trip?
What role does the definition of Immediate Family Member play in determining the applicability of Pre-Existing Medical Condition exclusions or coverage?
How does the policy handle claims if a Pre-Existing Medical Condition of a Travelling Companion leads to trip curtailment or additional expenses?
In what ways could the policy's definition of Pre-Existing Medical Condition affect claims related to quarantine or COVID-19 if symptoms existed prior to the Trip?
How does the policy address the timing of the commencement of the Trip in relation to the 182-day period for Pre-Existing Medical Conditions?
What challenges might arise in proving that a medical condition was not Pre-Existing under the policy's definition when symptoms were subtle or unrecognized before the Trip?
